awd_titl_txt: Computerized Adaptive Testing for Survey Research
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance computerized adaptive testing (CAT) as an alternative approach to static-reduced batteries.  A common way that social scientists learn about individuals' traits and beliefs is to have people answer many closely related questions about the same topic. These large multi-item batteries are used to measure constructs like personality traits, psychological illnesses, political ideology, personal values, levels of knowledge, and more.  Public opinion researchers, however, often choose not to use these widely respected multi-item batteries because of concerns regarding respondent burden or the costs of long surveys.  The standard solution is to select a subset of the available items, which then are administered to all respondents.  Such static-reduced batteries are well known to increase bias and lower measurement precision, however.  CAT ameliorates much of the decreased measurement precision and accuracy associated with static-reduced scales.  The project builds on existing work in the fields of educational testing and psychometrics to develop software and an online webservice that adopts and adjusts CAT for the specific needs of public opinion researchers.

This research project will apply CAT algorithms to the domain of survey research and provide practical resources and theoretical guidance specific to the needs of public opinion researchers.  CAT algorithms adapt dynamically to measure latent constructs while minimizing the number of questions each respondent must answer.  This approach uses information about the qualities of each question item to respond to individuals' prior answers by choosing subsequent questions that will place them on the latent dimension with maximum precision and a minimum number of questions. That is, it chooses questions for each respondent based on their previous responses so that researchers can learn as much as possible about the opinions of a respondent.  The project will provide basic software infrastructure necessary for developing CAT batteries and administering them on surveys. This includes the completion and hosting of a cloud-based webservice easily integrated into survey-administration software.  The project also will provide solutions to problems likely to confront survey researchers fielding adaptive batteries including appropriately handling high levels of measurement error and diagnosing flawed question-item calibrations. Finally, the project will collect data to build adaptive batteries measuring important concepts in the social sciences, with a special emphasis on personality inventories, using a combination of large convenience samples, a nationally representative sample, and existing datasets.  The distribution of these calibrations will allow researchers to use CAT techniques without the added cost of extensive pre-testing.

por.por_cntn:
This project addressed a common dilemma facing survey researchers - determining how to include large multi-item batteries given the time constraints of standard surveys. Many times, researchers want to study hard-to-measure traits like political knowledge, narcissism, or empathy. This is done by using a series of survey questions, called batteries, all designed to measure the same underlying trait.  But many established batteries for measuring these traits are very long.  Including them on surveys is too expensive, but how can we ask fewer questions and still measure these concepts well?

This project advanced an alternative - computerized adaptive testing (CAT) - that let’s researchers accurately measure important concepts with fewer questions. CAT algorithms adapt dynamically to measure these traits while minimizing the number of questions each respondent answers.

In all, the project resulted in three new pieces of open-sourced software, a free online webservice open to the public, ten new pre-trained survey batteries available to all researchers, a short textbook explaining the method and how to use it, and four peer reviewed articles. It also provided valuable training to students in the field of political methodology.

The most important output is the R package “catSurv” which provides a host of tools to make things as easy as possible for survey researchers using CAT batteries.  This was designed to be very fast and has many options appropriate for different kinds of survey batteries.

A second important output is a webservice that makes it easier to integrate CAT with standard survey tools.  The catSurv.com webervice allows researchers to utilize the functionality of the catSurv R package in their own work without having to do extensive coding or re-writing of software.  The website also provides instructions helping applied scholars integrate CAT into the popular Qualtrics survey software.

One obstacle to using CAT methods in surveys is that researchers need to “calibrate” the adaptive battery using large samples. To overcome this difficulty, the project assembled a large collection of responses to many of the most important batteries in the social sciences.  This allows researchers to use CAT batteries without having to go through the expensive process of calibrating them on their own.  These calibrations are freely available as part of the catSurv package and the data collected has been permanently archived for public use.

A fourth important outcome is a short Cambridge University Press book explaining the method to applied scholars as well as four additional peer reviewed publications either explaining, applying, or extending the approach.  These publications appeared in prestigious outlets including the Journal of Survey Statistics and Methodology, Political Analysis, Proceedings of the Thirty-Sixth Conference on Uncertainty in Artificial Intelligence, and the American Journal of Political Science.

Finally, the award also supported the training of multiple graduate students, including women interested in the field of political methodology.
